prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We tune our main baseband at a sky frequency of ~236.667 GHz in order to detect CO(4-3) in the merger located at a z=0.948. The remaining three bands are tuned to cover the thermal dust continuum emission. Since these are merging systems, we expect a large range of velocities and conservatively assume a width of 400 km/s for the CO(4-3) line. At a resolution of xxx MHz, we will resolve the line into 7 channels. This will be sufficient to distinguish the merging component of the source.

Our mergers have typical sizes of 1.2" and are separated by 0.5". We require an angular resolution of 0.5" to resolve the two merging cores and investigate the global dense gas kinematics. We assume that the largest angular scale is 2" in order to cover the whole emission of the sources. The separation is derived from the optical I-band images. The largest angular scales correspond to the extent of the optical flux. These are also in agreement with the source sizes observed at 3GHz with JVLA.

The CO(4-3) integrated flux density was estimated from the infrared luminosity (which gives the CO(1-0) luminosity) and assuming optically thick emission in order to convert CO(1-0) to CO(4-3) fluxes.
The continuum flux density at 1.3 mm was obtained from Herschel 250um fluxes by using a modified balckbody with Td=30K and B=1.5.
The size of our sources are 1.2" and the typical separation of their components is 0.5". Therfore, we select a resolution of 0.5" to just resolve the merging cores.
We assume that for each ALMA beam, the line and continuum emissio will be decreased by a factor (1.2/0.5)^2. We require a S/N of 5 for each channel line covering for a robust determination of the CO line and derive physical (gas) properties of the sources. Obtaining sufficient S/N on the line will yield a S/N of at least 5 for the continuum emission.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Understanding the fate of molecular gas in mergers is essential to understanding the subsequent evolution of post-merger galaxies. During the peak of cosmic star-formation from 3<z<1, a large fraction of galaxies undergo a major merger, making mergers an important evolutionary step. We propose spatially and spectrally resolved CO(4-3) observations of 5 merging galaxies at z~1 in the COSMOS field. These galaxies are optically-selected to be a few Myr from coalescence, at a time when merger-triggered star formation is thought to peak. These mergers are luminous infrared sources with SFRs larger than 100 Msun/yr. ALMA will provide spectrally and spatially resolved maps of the dense molecular gas in these systems. We will trace where in the merger star formation is occurring: in both merging galaxies, only one, or somewhere else. We will use the kinematic information from the spectra to look for rotational motion and inflows and outflows in the molecular gas. We will also derive integrated quantities such as the gas fraction and star formation efficiencies and compare these properties to those of mergers at different redshifts.
